title: Swiss Gold Bars Will Be Subject to Trump Tariffs
description: Gold prices surged overnight after the Trump administration said gold bars will be subject to tariffs. Traders, analysts and executives were left stunned since they thought bullion would be exempt from President Donald Trump's reciprocal tariffs. This is very bad news for Switzerland. Bloomberg's Oliver Crook reports.  (Source: Bloomberg)
content: And we're going to stick with trade right now, not just what's going on with India, but also what's going on with gold. And specifically, this really points to Switzerland. Gold futures in New York this morning surging to a record high after sources telling us at Bloomberg that Swiss gold bars are unexpectedly facing U.S. tariffs. Bloomberg's Oliver Crook joins us now. Oliver, what's going on? These tariffs going to stick? Yeah. I mean, if the Swiss needed any more bad news, which I don't think they really did, they got it overnight saying that basically, you know, a part of the gold market that they thought was going to be exempted, which is sort of smaller Swiss gold bars that are about 100 ounces to one kilogram. Those are actually now going to face tariffs. And you seen the reaction within the markets at a time when we had the Swiss president going to Washington, D.C., failing to speak to basically anybody on the Trump trade team, only getting a meeting with Marco Rubio, coming back to Switzerland and having this emergency meeting with a bunch of businesses. We spoke to some of these sort of representatives of businesses to Switzerland. And I think that that the takeaway is that they really are at this point at the mercy of the Trump administration. There was some discussions of how they could possibly retaliate, maybe canceling their orders for 35. They've got an order for 36 of those worth billions of dollars. But really, they can see they see that as only sort of worsening the situation. So, again, in a week that you had really colossally bad news for the Swiss, they're stuck with that 39% tariff. And so you're going to see it in the gold market, obviously, for watches. You guys, we're talking about luxury a little bit earlier, but also Nestle. Nestle is down 20% over the last month because all of the Nespresso capsules in the world are made in three plants and they're all in Switzerland. I thought you were right to say that Nespresso capsules are made with gold, and I was going to be shocked by some. I'm glad that's not the case, Oliver. But to your point, Switzerland considering retaliation. Maybe they won't do it as no other countries have. But what about a carrot all over? What could Switzerland possibly offer this administration to get them to back down from the most severe of tariff rates? Yeah, Danny, I mean, it might just be one of these sort of pay to play situations that you saw out of Japan that you're committing to, that hundreds of billions of dollars worth of funding to basically go to Trump where Trump says whatever I want, same thing that you got from the EU, that might be the route that they have to go. I think that basically what you saw is this is an administration, the Swiss, they thought they had a deal with Donald Trump. They thought they had it all locked and loaded. I'd spoken to the president a couple of months ago. She was feeling very good about that. And then suddenly that was not the case. I think he saw basically how big the deficit was, realizes how rich as a nation Switzerland is and was really very unhappy about that in turn. So I think it's going to probably be, you know, at some point unless they find some other creative way they tried to show up in Washington, D.C., might be just a function of writing a check, which seems to solve many of the problems with the Trump administration.
summary: Swiss gold bars are expected to be subject to U.S. tariffs, according to sources in Bloomberg. This comes as a surprise to the Swiss market, with a part of the gold market that they thought was exempt from being exempt. The move comes as the Swiss president, who had been meeting with the Trump trade team, failed to speak with any of them on the team, and they are now at the mercy of the Trump administration. The Swiss government had considered canceling orders for 35 Swiss gold bars worth billions of dollars, but they see this as worsening the situation. This could lead to a surge in the gold futures market for watches and luxury goods, with Nestle's Nespresso falling 20% over the last month as all of the world's world's top brands are made in Switzerland. Oliver Crook suggests that Switzerland may consider retaliation, but may not do so as no other countries have.
shortSummary: Swiss gold bars face unexpected tariffs of 39% under Trump's policies, causing market turmoil and potential retaliation.
argos_summary: Swiss gold bars are now facing unexpected U.S. tariffs, leading to a surge in gold futures in New York. The Swiss government, having previously believed certain gold products would be exempt, is now grappling with a 39% tariff and considering potential retaliatory measures. This situation has compounded existing economic challenges for Switzerland, including a significant decline in Nestle's stock due to its reliance on Swiss manufacturing.
